question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What was Timothy Allen's employer in 2018?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
"The Unseen Heroes of Emergency Medicine: The Story of Timothy Allen"

In the bustling streets of Quebec City, Canada, a quiet hero was making a name for himself in the world of emergency medicine. Dr. Timothy Allen, a Canadian emergency physician, was leaving an indelible mark on the medical community, and his work at Laval University was just the beginning. It was the early 2000s, and Laval University, a public research institution, was rapidly gaining recognition for its cutting-edge research and innovative approaches to healthcare. As a respected emergency physician, Timothy Allen was drawn to the university's commitment to excellence and its reputation for fostering a culture of collaboration and discovery. One of the most significant pieces of evidence supporting Timothy Allen's affiliation with Laval University is his involvement in a groundbreaking research project focused on improving emergency department wait times. In 2005, Allen co-authored a study published in the Canadian Journal of Emergency Medicine, which explored the impact of implementing a rapid assessment zone in emergency departments. The study, conducted in collaboration with Laval University researchers, demonstrated a significant reduction in wait times and improved patient outcomes. This research project not only showcased Allen's expertise in emergency medicine but also highlighted his commitment to advancing the field through evidence-based research. His collaboration with Laval University researchers was a testament to the university's reputation as a hub for innovative research and its ability to attract top talent in the medical field. Further evidence of Allen's work at Laval University can be found in his role as a guest lecturer at the university's Faculty of Medicine. In 2007, he delivered a series of lectures on emergency department management, sharing his expertise with the next generation of medical professionals. This opportunity not only allowed Allen to give back to the medical community but also demonstrated Laval University's commitment to providing its students with access to leading experts in the field. As Allen's reputation continued to grow, so did his involvement with Laval University. In 2010, he was appointed as a clinical professor at the university's Department of Emergency Medicine, a position that allowed him to mentor and inspire a new generation of emergency physicians. This appointment was a testament to Allen's dedication to education and his commitment to shaping the future of emergency medicine. Throughout his career, Timothy Allen's work at Laval University has left an indelible mark on the medical community. His research, teaching, and clinical practice have all contributed to a deeper understanding of emergency medicine and have improved patient outcomes.
content.source_2: In the year 2033, Dr. Timothy Allen, a seasoned Canadian emergency physician, embarked on a new chapter in his career. He left behind the familiar streets of Toronto and boarded a flight to Athens, Greece, where he would take on a prestigious role at the National and Kapodistrian University of Athens. As he settled into his new apartment in the heart of the city, Timothy couldn't help but feel a sense of excitement and trepidation. He had always been drawn to the rich history and culture of Greece, and the opportunity to work at one of the oldest and most respected universities in the country was a dream come true. Over the next three years, Timothy threw himself into his work, quickly earning the respect and admiration of his colleagues and students. He was tasked with developing and implementing new emergency medicine protocols, and his expertise in the field was invaluable to the university. As the years passed, Timothy became an integral part of the university community. He formed close bonds with his colleagues, including the Dean of the Medical School, Dr. Sophia Papadopoulos, who became a mentor and friend. Together, they worked tirelessly to improve the university's emergency response systems, and their efforts paid off when the university was awarded a prestigious grant to establish a state-of-the-art emergency medicine center. In 2035, Timothy's work took him to the forefront of a major crisis when a devastating earthquake struck Athens, causing widespread destruction and chaos. As the university's emergency response team sprang into action, Timothy played a crucial role in coordinating the relief efforts, working tirelessly to treat the injured and provide medical aid to those in need. As the city began to rebuild, Timothy's expertise was in high demand. He worked closely with government officials, emergency responders, and other medical professionals to develop a comprehensive disaster response plan, ensuring that the city was better prepared for future crises. In 2036, as Timothy's three-year contract came to an end, he was hailed as a hero and a pioneer in the field of emergency medicine. His work at the National and Kapodistrian University of Athens had left a lasting impact, and he had forged lifelong connections with the people and the city he had grown to love. As he boarded the flight back to Canada, Timothy felt a sense of nostalgia wash over him. He knew that he would always carry a piece of Athens with him, and that the experiences and lessons he had gained during his time at the university would stay with him forever.
